awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Framework for Ad Hoc Model Construction in Data Streaming Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past decade there has been an exponential growth in data volumes driven in part by data streams generated by computer programs and observational equipment such as satellites, radars, and ecological sensors. Given the data volumes, it can be difficult to harness the data to understand phenomena and/or to make forecasts. Fitting models to the observational data is one way to accomplish this. A precursor to building such models is extracting features from the data. Models constructed using such features can then be used to predict what the outcome will be and when it is likely to happen.  This research will provide scientists and researchers the tools needed to make sense of data streams generated in streaming environments. Domains where this research is broadly applicable include smart cities, traffic planning, homeland security, and ecological monitoring. The project includes an educational component focused on increasing female student participation in college STEM majors. Therefore, this project aligns with the NSF mission to promote the progress of science, to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare, and to secure the national defense.

The project aims to carry out research to create an enabling infrastructure to support the generation, assessment, and refinement of ad hoc models from voluminous, multidimensional, time-series observational data at scale. Challenges in ad hoc model creation stem from the combinatorially explosive number of ways in which models can be realized. The framework, Synapse, aims to support and simplify the naturally iterative and interactive model building process over voluminous streaming data. Modelers will only need to specify a basic set of bootstrap parameters; the framework will manage complexities relating to: (1) how streams are dispersed, (2) how data accesses are managed, (3) coping with I/O and memory contentions, and (4) dispersion of model generation workloads. The research involves scalable techniques for data dispersion employing distributed hash table data structures, map-reduce-based workflows and orchestration of model creation workloads, training data management, and interactive visual assessment of model performance. A visualization component will allow modelers to quickly and effectively assess the quality of a multiplicity of models each possibly covering a different portion of the input feature space and to use these assessments to guide decisions about selection, updates or replacements of models. If successful, the framework will scale with increases in data volumes, the number of available data streams, model generation workloads, and live model evaluations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Fueled by the proliferation of IoT devices and an increased adoption of sensing environments, there has been an explosive growth in the  availability of spatiotemporal data collections in recent years. The research objective of this effort is to design an enabling infrastructure to support the generation, assessment, and refinement of ad hoc models from voluminous, multidimensional, time-series observational data at scale.  

We have investigated research topics in large-scale data analytics over voluminous spatiotemporal datasets. Disk based storage systems provide reliable archivals but are far too slow for efficient analytics. As part of this project, we have designed and developed large-scale distributed frameworks that encompass in-memory and disk-based architectures. 

Also, our research focused on large-scale geospatial model training and orchestration of computational workloads. Deep learning models are computationally and resource expensive. As dataset sizes increase, there is a corresponding increase in the CPU, GPU, disk, and network I/O requirements to train models. Our approach encompasses partitioning, reconstruction, and refinement of large high dimensional geospatial data. 

We  investigated the design of novel sketching algorithms and systems optimizations to construct and train models with significantly reduced time and storage requirements. These sketching algorithms were aligned with the spatiotemporal characteristics of the data and facilitate analytic operations at scale.

Finally, we have explored methodologies to achieve scalable data storage and retrieval for scientific discovery. Interactive geospatial visualization is an intuitive tool to identify patterns, enhance understanding of the data, and plan for subsequent analysis. We have designed a distributed data structure that allows users to cache, query and retrieve aggregated values with multiple granularities over large scale data collections. These efforts were complemented with an in-memory distributed geospatial storage that preserves spatial proximity and enables proactive auto-scaling for frequently accessed data. 

 

This CAREER project has resulted in 17 journal publications, 21 conference papers, 1 workshop paper, 4 research posters, 3 Ph.D. dissertations, and 17 Master?s degrees. One of the Ph.D. student?s supported by this effort, Matthew Malensek, was honored with the IEEE Technical Committee for Scalable Computing?s Outstanding Ph.D. Dissertation Award in 2018. Two of our conference papers received the Best Paper award at IEEE CLUSTER 2019 and IEEE BDCAT 2019.  One of the conference papers was nominated as the finalist for the best paper award at IEEE BDCLOUD2018.  

In addition, 5 Ph.D. students and 2 M.S. students are pursuing their degree as part of this research.   There have been 3 REU students supported by this effort  and two of them are currently pursuing graduate degrees under PI?s supervision.

For the project period (since 2016), we have designed, developed, and hosted a summer STEM camp series for female students in high schools to emphasize opportunities for majoring in computer science. SWiFT (Summer Computer Science STEM Camp for Women in Fort Collins) is a non-residential summer camp and has had more than 70 participants in the 5 summer camps, and more than 90% of the campers had not programmed before. A total 17 undergraduate instructors were employed for SWiFT and 19 mentors contributed to the SWiFT summer camp series. 

 


 

 


Last Modified: 07/14/2022
Modified by: Sangmi Pallickara

We  investigated the design of novel sketching algorithms and systems optimizations to construct and train models with significantly reduced time and storage requirements.
